Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Parasites of Australian Turtles: Unknown Aspects of Biodiversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project examines the parasites of Australia's most common freshwater turtles. Turtles are an evolutionarily ancient group with a fascinating and diverse parasite fauna. It is anticipated that the project will recover representatives of six major parasite groups (phyla) and a substantial majority of the more than 100 parasite species thought to be new to science. Parasites will be collected, cataloged, identified and described as part of the project and deposited to form a public specimen base in both Australia and the United States. Although these parasites have been implicated in host disease almost nothing is known about them outside of North America.

Information and data from these studies will be made available directly to Australian turtle researchers and to the public through the project's WWW site. In addition to uncovering unknown aspects of Australia's biodiversity the project will generate data and specimens necessary to test a variety of hypotheses concerning parasite biodiversity, biogeography and evolution. These hypotheses provide synthetic areas of study ideal for training broadly educated students. Data from the project will inform not only studies of biodiversity, ecology and evolution, but also will be valuable to regulatory agencies involved in turtle conservation.

Institution.Name: University of North Dakota Main Campus

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Dakota Main Campus

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this collaborative project between the University of Nebraska at Omaha (UNO) and the University of North Dakota (UND) were to collect, catalog, describe, and provide broad public access to the Australian freshwater turtle parasite fauna and associated host and distributional data. Although the biology and conservation status of the Australian turtle fauna is relatively well known, knowledge of the parasites of these turtles was lacking. Thorough knowledge of the parasite biodiversity is a necessary first step towards understanding the impact of parasites on turtle populations. The funded project has taken this step with collections of turtles and parasites from nearly every region of Australia inhabited by turtles. The project produced descriptions of 18 parasite species new to science and additional descriptions are forthcoming. This work contributes to the discipline of parasitology and to other areas of biology by increasing awareness of the wealth of hidden biodiversity represented by parasites. The project provides evidence that both geography and climate shape the evolutionary history of turtle parasite biodiversity in Australia. The project produced a specimen base of several thousand parasite specimens which will result in additional publications related to parasite population genetics, distribution, evolution and identification. A large number of type and voucher specimens have been deposited with the Queensland Museum and H.W. Manter Laboratory of Parasitology at the University of Nebraska. The remaining specimens will also be deposited in the museum collections and become accessible to researchers and public. These materials provide a basis for testing hypotheses concerning parasite biodiversity, biogeography and evolution, and provide data for conservation and management decisions. A large number of DNA sequences have been deposited in GenBank and are available to other researchers, animal health professionals and the public. Tissue samples of over 200 turtles have been preserved for molecular analyses and archived at the University of Canberra, Australia and in museum collections. Fifteen manuscripts were published in peer-reviewed journals and an additional six as book chapters, with additional publications forthcoming. The project fostered international collaboration between four universities in the U.S. and four research institutions in Australia and the Ukraine. The project website contains comprehensive information about parasites of Australian freshwater turtles and main project activities (http://www.und.nodak.edu/instruct/vtkach/ATP/index.htm).

Students were active participants at all stages of this work. During the term of the project 18 undergraduates (5 from UNO, 13 from UND) and 2 high school students (at UND) have had the opportunity to participate in mentored laboratory research related to the project. These students included females, a Native American student and two first generation college students from rural areas. Two female Hispanic graduate students were being funded to conduct their research on aspects of the project at UNO and have successfully completed their degrees. All students have been trained in numerous classical and modern parasitological techniques. Most of them presented the results of this work at scientific meetings. More importantly, majority of the undergraduate students have been accepted to various professional and graduate programs upon graduation from UND and UNO. The project resulted in 25 platform presentations and two Master’s theses. Scientific specimens, DNA samples, quantitative data and photographs taken as part of the project were used extensively by both PIs in introductory biology, upper level courses, public seminar and on the Web. This has allowed us to expose students to notions of biodiversity, syst...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objectives of this collaborative project between the University of Nebraska at Omaha (UNO) and the University of North Dakota (UND) were to collect, catalog, describe, and provide broad public access to the Australian freshwater turtle parasite fauna and associated host and distributional data. Although the biology and conservation status of the Australian turtle fauna is relatively well known, knowledge of the parasites of these turtles was lacking. Thorough knowledge of the parasite biodiversity is a necessary first step towards understanding the impact of parasites on turtle populations. The funded project has taken this step with collections of turtles and parasites from nearly every region of Australia inhabited by turtles. The project produced descriptions of 18 parasite species new to science and additional descriptions are forthcoming. This work contributes to the discipline of parasitology and to other areas of biology by increasing awareness of the wealth of hidden biodiversity represented by parasites. The project provides evidence that both geography and climate shape the evolutionary history of turtle parasite biodiversity in Australia. The project produced a specimen base of several thousand parasite specimens which will result in additional publications related to parasite population genetics, distribution, evolution and identification. A large number of type and voucher specimens have been deposited with the Queensland Museum and H.W. Manter Laboratory of Parasitology at the University of Nebraska. The remaining specimens will also be deposited in the museum collections and become accessible to researchers and public. These materials provide a basis for testing hypotheses concerning parasite biodiversity, biogeography and evolution, and provide data for conservation and management decisions. A large number of DNA sequences have been deposited in GenBank and are available to other researchers, animal health professionals and the public. Tissue samples of over 200 turtles have been preserved for molecular analyses and archived at the University of Canberra, Australia and in museum collections. Fifteen manuscripts were published in peer-reviewed journals and an additional six as book chapters, with additional publications forthcoming. The project fostered international collaboration between four universities in the U.S. and four research institutions in Australia and the Ukraine. The project website contains comprehensive information about parasites of Australian freshwater turtles and main project activities (http://www.und.nodak.edu/instruct/vtkach/ATP/index.htm). Students were active participants at all stages of this work. During the term of the project 18 undergraduates (5 from UNO, 13 from UND) and 2 high school students (at UND) have had the opportunity to participate in mentored laboratory research related to the project. These students included females, a Native American student and two first generation college students from rural areas. Two female Hispanic graduate students were being funded to conduct their research on aspects of the project at UNO and have successfully completed their degrees. All students have been trained in numerous classical and modern parasitological techniques. Most of them presented the results of this work at scientific meetings. More importantly, majority of the undergraduate students have been accepted to various professional and graduate programs upon graduation from UND and UNO. The project resulted in 25 platform presentations and two MasterÆs theses. Scientific specimens, DNA samples, quantitative data and photographs taken as part of the project were used extensively by both PIs in introductory biology, upper level courses, public seminar and on the Web. This has allowed us to expose students to notions of biodiversity, systematics and field biology with a personal perspective. Last Modified: 03/21/2011 Submitted by: Vasyl V Tkach
